questionnaireInfo.text: Welcome to the Baby Laughter Survey!   This research is being conducted by Dr. Caspar Addyman and colleagues from the Babylab at Birkbeck, University of London. We are interested in finding out what exactly makes your baby laugh? You can't laugh if you don't get the joke. You don't laugh if you're not happy and in good company. So by studying what makes babies laugh we can gain new insights into their understanding of the world and how they interact with people around them.    We'd like to know who and what your baby finds funny. We'd like know what toys are always sure to raise a smile and what games can guarantee hysterics. What's more, we'd like to know what you think your baby is thinking when they find something amusing.    Your participation in this survey is much appreciated and the input you have to offer is invaluable. This survey take no more than 15 minutes to finish. Don't worry if a certain little someone needs your attention, you can save your answers and come back to it later.    Remember all information will be analyzed and kept strictly confidential so feel free to answer all questions as honestly and truthfully as possible.   If you have any questions feel free to email Dr Caspar Addyman.

Thank you very much for your participation.

 

 

You can follow the progress of our research on our blog.

 

 

If something particularly funny happens, there is a short form on our site that you can use to send us a 'field report'

 

Please tell your friends.

var switchTo5x=true; stLight.options({publisher: "c22a30ad-199e-4063-98d6-5d24c2d9cc46"});

sectionInfo.text: Welcome to The Baby Laughter Questionnaire

Your participation is much appreciated! This survey should only take about 15 minutes to complete.
All the information you provide us with will be treated as confidential, and analysed anonymously. Just fill in the information below and click 'submit' to get started!
If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to email us: infantologist@gmail.com

question.text: Consent   By checking this option you indicate that you understand that participation is voluntary and that you are free to withdraw at any time, without giving any reason, without your legal rights being affected. Remember all information will be analyzed and kept strictly confidential so feel free to answer all questions as honestly and truthfully as possible. Please check the box below to confirm that you have read and understood the above information about this online questionnaire and have had the opportunity to ask questions (by emailing Dr. Caspar Addyman).

category.label: I agree to take part in the above study

question.text:
Email Address (optional)
If you would like to be emailed a summary of our results please provide your email address below.
Your details will not be forwarded to any third parties. Your email address is only requested for correspondence purposes.

This questionnaire is part of ongoing research conducted by the Baby Lab at Birbeck University.
If you would be happy for your email address to be kept on record so that you can be contacted with information about future studies and invitations to take part please check the box below.

category.label: I am happy to be contacted about future Baby Lab studies
I am already registered with Birkbeck Baby Lab

question.text: In what country do you currently reside?

category.label: The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia

question.text: If you live in the U.K. select your distance from Central London

sectionInfo.text: Baby background
Please start by providing is with some general background information about you and your baby.

question.text: Please enter your baby's birth date.
Baby gender:

If completing on behalf of twins, please give answers that would be generally true for both of them. If you would prefer you can do the survey separately for each baby.

 

Are your twins?

If completing on behalf of triplets, etc, please give answers that would be generally true for all of them. If you would prefer you can do the survey separately for each baby.

  What sex are you babies? Are they identical?
How many older brothers and sisters does your baby have?
What are their ages and genders?
Is there anything else we should know about your baby? (e.g. Where there any problems with the birth? Does your baby have any illness or condition?)
Please describe
What is the highest level of education the mother of the child has completed?
What is the highest level of education the father of the child has completed?
What job does the mother currently hold?
What job does the father currently hold?

sectionInfo.text: Earliest Laughs
Please tell us about your baby's earliest laughs and smiles

question.text: Can you remember the age of your baby's first laughs and smiles. (If unsure or not relevant, please leave blank)

subQuestion.text: First deliberate smile (when asked to smile)

question.text: Can you remember what caused your baby's first laugh? If so, please describe what happened.
What is the most memorable example of your baby laughing?
What is the one thing that is sure to make your baby laugh?
What does your baby do that makes YOU laugh?

sectionInfo.text: The Causes of Baby Laughter

From Freud onwards psychologists have speculated about the causes of laughter and philosophers having been wondering about humour since the ancient Greeks. We are interested in how relevant you think these ideas might be to your baby's laughter.

question.text:
Thinking about what causes your baby to laugh, please decide how relevant is each of these factors  might be. Please rate each item on a scale of 0-10, putting 0 for anything is completely irrelevant and 10 for anything is always true when your baby is laughing.

Please give answers which are true for your baby at their current age.

subQuestion.text: Response to a pleasant sensation (eg tickling)
Response to a sudden or surprising event (eg boo!)
Response to something silly or unusual (eg a dog going 'miouw')
Response to exaggerated event or action
When fear is averted (eg something that seemed scary turns out not to be)
Because baby knows he/she is being naughty

question.text: Did we forget anything? Tell us your theory about why your baby laughs

sectionInfo.text: People That Make Your Baby Laugh
People that are currently in your baby's life, whether they are immediate or distant family members, neighbors, other babies or just random strangers. Who makes your baby laugh the most or least?

question.text: Please indicate the level that each person makes your baby laugh. If there are any people that we forgot, please add them in the box below. If any question does not apply to you and your baby please put "No answer"

category.label: My baby finds this person hysterical

question.text: Who does your baby think is the funniest people they know?
Did we forget anyone? If so, who?

sectionInfo.text: At Home
What times of day and bits of your daily routine make your baby giggle while at home?

question.text:
At what times of day does your baby laugh the most?  

If any question does not apply please put "No answer"

What aspects of daily routine make your baby laugh the most?  

If any question does not apply please put "No answer"
Did we forget any part of your daily routine that your baby finds funny? If so, what?
How many times a day would you say your baby laughs?
What TV shows does your baby find the funniest?

sectionInfo.text: Out and About
When you and your baby are out running errands or perhaps having a fun time, what does your baby laugh at?

question.text:
Please indicate the level that each situation makes your baby laugh when your are out and about. 

If any question does not apply to you please put "No answer"

Transport:
Places:
Did we forget anything or anywhere?
Where are your baby's favorite places to visit?
Do you remember a particularly funny trip? If so, what made the baby laugh?

What toys and games does your baby find funny?

question.text:
Please go through the following list of toys and indicate the how much each one makes your baby laugh.

If any question does not apply to you please put "No answer"

 

Toys:

question.text: Did we forget any games that make your baby laugh?
What games does your baby find the funniest?

sectionInfo.text: Sensations
Touch, feel, smell, sight and taste. What specific sensations really make your baby laugh?

question.text: Please indicate the level that each sensation makes your baby laugh.

subQuestion.text: Music (For Parents, Your Choice of Music)

category.label: My baby finds this sensation hysterical

question.text: If your baby does find certain smells or tastes funny, what are they?
Did we forget any sensations? If so, what?
What physical sensation does your baby find the funniest?

sectionInfo.text: Nearly done!
Is there anything that we forgot that really makes your baby laugh? Please tell us now

question.text: What did we forget? If any group or subject that makes your baby laugh has not been covered in this questionnaire, this is your last chance to let us know what really makes your baby laugh!
Do you have any questions for us?

Are you willing to answer some extra questions about your baby's temperament?

This final section is completely optional. It includes 37 extra multiple choice questions and takes about 10 mins to complete.  

To come back and answer these questions later, press the button at the bottom left.

category.label: Yes, my baby is less than 1 year old
Yes, my baby is 1 year old or older

sectionInfo.text: Less Than 1 Year Old

INSTRUCTIONS:
Please read carefully before starting:
As you read each description of the baby’s behavior below, please indicate how often the baby did this during the LAST WEEK (the past seven days) by circling one of the numbers in the left column.
The “Does Not Apply” (X) column is used when you did not see the baby in the situation described during the last week. For example, if the situation mentions the baby having to wait for food or liquids and there was no time during the last week when the baby had to wait, circle the (X) column. “Does Not Apply” is different from “Never” (1). “Never” is used when you saw the baby in the situation but the baby never engaged in the behavior listed during the last week. For example, if the baby did have to wait for food or liquids at least once but never cried loudly while waiting, circle the (1) column.
Please be sure to circle a number for every item.

question.text: Please indicate how often the baby did this during the LAST WEEK

subQuestion.text: When being dressed or undressed during the last week, how often did the baby squirm and/or try to roll away?
When tossed around playfully how often did the baby laugh?
When tired, how often did your baby show distress?
When introduced to an unfamiliar adult, how often did the baby cling to a parent?
How often during the last week did the baby enjoy being read to?
How often during the last week did the baby play with one toy or object for 5-10 minutes?
How often during the week did your baby move quickly toward new objects?
When put into the bath water, how often did the baby laugh?
When it was time for bed or a nap and your baby did not want to go, how often did s/he whimper or sob?
After sleeping, how often did the baby cry if someone doesn’t come within a few minutes?
In the last week, while being fed in your lap, how often did the baby seem eager to get away as soon as the feeding was over?
When singing or talking to your baby, how often did s/he soothe immediately?
When placed on his/her back, how often did the baby squirm and/or turn body?
During a peekaboo game, how often did the baby laugh?
How often does the infant look up from playing when the telephone rings?
How often did the baby seem angry (crying and fussing) when you left her/him in the crib?
How often during the last week did the baby startle at a sudden change in body position (e.g., when moved suddenly)?
How often during the last week did the baby enjoy hearing the sound of words, as in nursery rhymes?
How often during the last week did the baby look at pictures in books and/or magazines for 5 minutes or longer at a time?
When visiting a new place, how often did your baby get excited about exploring new surroundings?
How often during the last week did the baby smile or laugh when given a toy?
At the end of an exciting day, how often did your baby become tearful?
How often during the last week did the baby protest being placed in a confining place (infant seat, play pen, car seat, etc.)?
When being held, in the last week, did your baby seem to enjoy him/herself?
When showing the baby something to look at, how often did s/he soothe immediately?
When hair was washed, how often did the baby vocalize?
How often did your baby notice the sound of an airplane passing overhead?
When introduced to an unfamiliar adult, how often did the baby refuse to go to the unfamiliar person?
When you were busy with another activity, and your baby was not able to get your attention, how often did s/he cry?
How often during the last week did the baby enjoy gentle rhythmic activities, such as rocking or swaying?
How often during the last week did the baby stare at a mobile, crib bumper or picture for 5 minutes or longer?
When the baby wanted something, how often did s/he become upset when s/he could not get what s/he wanted?
When in the presence of several unfamiliar adults, how often did the baby cling to a parent?
When rocked or hugged, in the last week, did your baby seem to enjoy him/herself?
When patting or gently rubbing some part of the baby’s body, how often did s/he soothe immediately?
How often did your baby make talking sounds when riding in a car?
When placed in an infant seat or car seat, how often did the baby squirm and turn body?

sectionInfo.text: 1 Year or Older

INSTRUCTIONS:
Please read carefully before starting:
As you read each description of the baby’s behavior below, please indicate how often the baby did this during the LAST WEEK (the past seven days) by circling one of the numbers in the left column.
The “Does Not Apply” (X) column is used when you did not see the baby in the situation described during the last week. For example, if the situation mentions the baby having to wait for food or liquids and there was no time during the last week when the baby had to wait, circle the (X) column. “Does Not Apply” is different from “Never” (1). “Never” is used when you saw the baby in the situation but the baby never engaged in the behavior listed during the last week. For example, if the baby did have to wait for food or liquids at least once but never cried loudly while waiting, circle the (1) column.
Please be sure to circle a number for every item.

question.text: Please indicate how often the baby did this during the LAST WEEK.

subQuestion.text: When approached by an unfamiliar person in a public place (for example, the grocery store), how often did your child cling to a parent?
While having trouble completing a task (e.g., building, drawing, dressing), how often did your child get easily irritated?
When a familiar child came to your home, how often did your child seek out the company of the child?
When offered a choice of activities, how often did your child decide what to do very quickly and go after it?
During daily or evening quiet time with you and your child, how often did your child enjoy just being quietly sung to?
While playing outdoors, how often did your child choose to take chances for the fun and excitement of it?
When engaged in play with his/her favorite toy, how often did your child play for more than 10 minutes?
When engaged in play with his/her favorite toy, how often did your child continue to play while at the same time responding to your remarks or questions?
When told that loved adults would visit, how often did your child get very excited
During quiet activities, such as reading a story, how often did your child fiddle with his/her hair, clothing, etc.?
While playing indoors, how often did your child like rough and rowdy games?
When being gently rocked or hugged, how often did your child seem eager to get away?
When encountering a new activity, how often did your child get involved immediatley?
When engaged in an activity requiring attention, such as building with blocks, how often did your child tire of the activity relatively quickly?
During everyday activities, how often did your child pay attention to you right away when you called to him/her?
During everyday activities, how often did your child seem to be irritated by tags in his/her clothes?
During everyday activities, how often did your child become bothered by sounds while in noisy environments?
During everyday activities, how often did your child seem full of energy, even in the evening?
While in a public place, how often did your child seem afraid of large, noisy vehicles?
When playing outdoors with other children, how often did your child seem to be one of the most active children?
When told “no”, how often did your child stop the forbidden activity?
When told “no”, how often did your child become sadly tearful?
Following an exciting activity or event, how often did your child seem to feel down or blue?
While playing indoors, how often did your child run through the house?
Before an exciting event (such as receiving a new toy), how often did your child get very excited about getting it?
When s/he asked for something and you said “no”, how often did your child have a temper tantrum?
When asked to wait for a desirable item (such as ice cream), how often did your child wait patiently?
When being gently rocked, how often did your child smile?
While being held on your lap, how often did your child mold to your body?
When a familiar adult, such as a relative or friend, visited your home, how often did your child want to interact with the adult?
When asked to do so, how often was your child able to be careful with something breakable?
When visiting a new place, how often did your child not want to enter?
When s/he was upset, how often did your child cry for more than 3 minutes, even when being comforted?
When s/he was upset, how often did your child become easily soothed?
When you were busy, how often did your child find another activity to do when asked?
When around large gatherings of familiar adults or children, how often did your child enjoy playing with a number of different people?
